title: 107_hr920
content: The Act is titled the "21st Century Election Rules and Technology Act" and establishes a commission with specified membership. The "21st Century Election Rules and Technology Act" establishes the Federal Elections Review Commission (referred to as the Commission) with 12 members appointed by the Senate and House leaders to study and make recommendations on the integrity and public confidence in Federal elections. The Federal Elections Review Commission, established by the "21st Century Election Rules and Technology Act," consists of 12 members appointed by Senate and House leaders. Members must have expertise in election laws, technology, the Constitution, and US history, and should not be US officers or employees. Efforts are made to ensure diverse regional and political perspectives among members for fresh insights on the Federal electoral process. The Federal Elections Review Commission, established by the "21st Century Election Rules and Technology Act," consists of 12 members appointed by Senate and House leaders. Members must have expertise in election laws, technology, the Constitution, and US history, and should not be US officers or employees. Efforts are made to ensure diverse regional and political perspectives among members for fresh insights on the Federal electoral process. The Commission shall be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment, with appointments for life. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission shall hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, elect a chairperson and vice chairperson, and meet at the call of the chairperson. The Commission shall meet at the call of the chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for business transactions. Each member's vote holds equal weight in determining the Commission's duties. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining the Federal electoral process, making recommendations to ensure integrity and public confidence in elections. Specific issues to be addressed include election technology, voter registration, and technologies to aid voters with disabilities. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993, also known as the "Motor Voter Act," and the accuracy of voter registration rolls are key issues to be addressed by the Commission. Other important topics include ballot access issues, such as mail-in balloting in Federal elections and the possibility of fraud, as well as the financial and resource needs of State and local election agencies. Additionally, the feasibility and advisability of voting through the Internet and the impact of polling place closing times are areas of concern for the Commission. The Commission will also consider the impact of ballot design, technology used for voting, language on ballots, and options for redress of electoral irregularities. The Commission will submit a final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for addressing identified problems to the President, Federal Election Commission, and Congress within 12 months of its initial meeting. Members can include separate views in the report. The Commission is granted powers. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Commission has the authority to appoint staff, including an executive director, whose pay should not exceed a certain level. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. $2,000,000 is authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act.
